q_gram_c2_12_010.explanation: 'Llevar las de ganar' is a fixed idiomatic structure meaning 'to have the upper hand / to be in a winning position'. The verb 'llevar' cannot be replaced by 'tener' or 'ganar' in this construction. The preterite 'llevó' indicates the advantage was achieved at a specific past moment.
q_gram_c2_12_010.conjugation_info: llevar (pretérito indefinido): llevé, llevaste, llevó, llevamos, llevasteis, llevaron

q_gram_c2_13_001.question: Vi al hombre con el ___ . (Which word resolves the ambiguity of 'I saw the man with the telescope'?)
q_gram_c2_13_001.explanation: The sentence 'Vi al hombre con el telescopio' is structurally ambiguous: 'con el telescopio' can modify 'vi' (I saw using the telescope) or 'al hombre' (the man who had the telescope). This is classic PP-attachment ambiguity. The fill-in itself is unambiguous — 'telescopio' is the instrument — but the sentence structure remains ambiguous.
q_gram_c2_13_001.hint: The prepositional phrase 'con el telescopio' can attach to two different elements

q_gram_c2_13_002.question: Cada estudiante entregó ___ trabajo a su profesor. (possessive that creates ambiguity)
q_gram_c2_13_002.explanation: 'Su' creates referential ambiguity: 'su trabajo' could mean 'his/her own work' or 'his/her (someone else's) work', and 'su profesor' could refer to each student's own professor or someone else's. This possessive ambiguity is inherent in Spanish because 'su' covers his/her/its/your/their.

q_gram_c2_13_003.question: What type of ambiguity does the sentence 'Juan le dijo a Pedro que lo ascendieron' contain?
q_gram_c2_13_003.correct: Referential ambiguity — 'lo' could refer to either Juan or Pedro, making it unclear who was promoted
wrong: Lexical ambiguity — the word 'ascendieron' has multiple dictionary meanings
Structural ambiguity — the subordinate clause can attach to different parts of the sentence
Pragmatic ambiguity — the sentence is ambiguous only in certain cultural contexts
q_gram_c2_13_003.explanation: In 'Juan le dijo a Pedro que lo ascendieron', the pronoun 'lo' could refer to either Juan or Pedro. Did Juan tell Pedro that Juan himself was promoted, or that Pedro was promoted? This is referential (or pronominal) ambiguity, common in Spanish due to the flexibility of pronoun reference.

q_gram_c2_13_004.question: No todos los estudiantes ___ a la reunión. (asistir, pretérito indefinido — this sentence means something different from 'Todos los estudiantes no asistieron')
q_gram_c2_13_004.explanation: Scope ambiguity arises with quantifiers and negation. 'No todos asistieron' (not all attended = some did, some didn't) differs from 'Todos no asistieron' (all of them didn't attend = none attended). The preterite 'asistieron' is used for a completed past event.
q_gram_c2_13_004.conjugation_info: asistir (pretérito indefinido): asistí, asististe, asistió, asistimos, asististeis, asistieron

q_gram_c2_13_005.question: La decisión del comité ___ ejecutivo provocó controversia. (Choose the word that shows how punctuation/structure resolves ambiguity.)
q_gram_c2_13_005.explanation: 'La decisión del comité más ejecutivo' is ambiguous: does 'más ejecutivo' modify 'comité' (the most executive committee) or 'la decisión' (the most executive decision of the committee)? Inserting 'más' exposes the structural ambiguity of adjective attachment in Spanish nominal groups.
q_gram_c2_13_005.hint: Consider how the comparative adjective can modify either the committee or the decision

q_gram_c2_13_006.question: Los padres de los alumnos que ___ molestos presentaron una queja formal. (estar, pretérito imperfecto — who was upset: the parents or the students?)
q_gram_c2_13_006.explanation: This sentence contains relative clause attachment ambiguity: 'que estaban molestos' could modify 'los padres' (the parents who were upset) or 'los alumnos' (the parents of the students who were upset). The imperfect 'estaban' describes the ongoing state. Only context or rephrasing can resolve the ambiguity.
q_gram_c2_13_006.conjugation_info: estar (pretérito imperfecto): estaba, estabas, estaba, estábamos, estabais, estaban

q_gram_c2_13_007.question: La profesora habló con ___ estudiante en su despacho. (article that preserves maximum ambiguity)
q_gram_c2_13_007.explanation: 'La profesora habló con el estudiante en su despacho' contains double ambiguity: (1) 'su despacho' could be the professor's office or the student's office (possessive ambiguity), and (2) 'en su despacho' could modify 'habló' (where the conversation took place) or 'el estudiante' (the student who is in the office). The definite article 'el' maximizes this ambiguity.

q_gram_c2_13_008.question: I told my brother that his wife called him. (Translate to preserve the pronominal ambiguity inherent in the Spanish version.)
q_gram_c2_13_008.correct: Le dije a mi hermano que su esposa lo llamó.
wrong: Dije a mi hermano que la esposa de él lo llamó.
Le dije a mi hermano que su mujer le había llamado.
Le conté a mi hermano que su esposa lo había telefoneado.
q_gram_c2_13_008.explanation: The translation 'Le dije a mi hermano que su esposa lo llamó' preserves the referential ambiguity of 'su' (his/my?) and 'lo' (him = my brother? or someone else?). Using 'la esposa de él' would disambiguate the possessive, losing the natural ambiguity. The preterite 'llamó' matches the simple past tense.

q_gram_c2_13_009.question: María no ___ que todos los candidatos fueran competentes. (creer, pretérito imperfecto — this creates scope ambiguity between negation and the universal quantifier)
q_gram_c2_13_009.explanation: 'María no creía que todos los candidatos fueran competentes' has scope ambiguity: (1) María believed not all were competent (partial negation: some were, some weren't), or (2) María didn't hold the belief that all were competent (she had no opinion). The imperfect 'creía' describes her ongoing state of belief, and the subjunctive 'fueran' is triggered by the negated belief verb.
q_gram_c2_13_009.conjugation_info: creer (pretérito imperfecto): creía, creías, creía, creíamos, creíais, creían

q_gram_c2_13_010.question: El policía detuvo al sospechoso en su coche.
q_gram_c2_13_010.correct: The police officer detained the suspect in his car. (Ambiguous: whose car — the officer's or the suspect's?)
wrong: The police officer stopped the suspect who was in the car. (Unambiguous: the suspect was in the car.)
The police officer was detained by the suspect in a car. (Passive reading: the suspect detained the officer.)
The officer stopped his own suspect inside the vehicle. (Unambiguous: the officer's own car.)
q_gram_c2_13_010.explanation: 'En su coche' creates possessive ambiguity: 'su' could refer to the officer's car or the suspect's car. Additionally, 'en su coche' could be an adverbial modifier of 'detuvo' (where the arrest happened) or a postmodifier of 'al sospechoso' (the suspect who was in the car). The correct translation preserves both layers of ambiguity.

q_gram_c2_14_001.question: En el presente estudio se ___ las variables que inciden en el rendimiento académico. (analizar, present indicative, impersonal 'se')
q_gram_c2_14_001.explanation: Academic Spanish uses impersonal 'se' constructions to maintain objectivity. Since 'las variables' is plural, the verb must agree: 'se analizan las variables'. The present tense is standard for describing the scope and methodology of the current study.
q_gram_c2_14_001.conjugation_info: analizar (present): analizo, analizas, analiza, analizamos, analizáis, analizan

q_gram_c2_14_002.question: Los datos ___ recopilados mediante una encuesta diseñada ad hoc para esta investigación.
q_gram_c2_14_002.explanation: Academic writing uses the passive voice with 'ser + past participle' to emphasize the process over the agent. 'Los datos fueron recopilados' (the data were collected) uses the preterite passive because data collection was a completed past action. 'Estuvieron recopilados' would incorrectly describe a resulting state rather than an action.
q_gram_c2_14_002.hint: Use the preterite of 'ser' to form the passive voice for a completed past action

q_gram_c2_14_003.question: Cabe ___ que los resultados podrían verse afectados por el tamaño reducido de la muestra.
q_gram_c2_14_003.explanation: 'Cabe señalar que...' (it should be noted that / it is worth pointing out that) is a fixed hedging expression in academic Spanish. 'Caber' + infinitive is an impersonal construction used to introduce observations or caveats. Only the infinitive form follows 'cabe' in this structure.
q_gram_c2_14_003.hint: The verb 'caber' takes an infinitive complement in this fixed academic expression

q_gram_c2_14_004.question: What is the function of nominalization in academic Spanish, as in 'la obtención de resultados' instead of 'obtener resultados'?
q_gram_c2_14_004.correct: It converts verbs into nouns to create more formal, impersonal, and information-dense prose typical of scientific writing
wrong: It simplifies complex ideas by replacing long verb phrases with shorter noun equivalents
It is primarily a stylistic choice with no functional difference from using verb phrases
It makes texts more accessible to non-specialist readers by eliminating technical verb forms
q_gram_c2_14_004.explanation: Nominalization (turning verbs into nouns: obtener → la obtención) is a hallmark of academic register in Spanish. It serves multiple functions: increasing information density, enabling impersonal expression, allowing noun phrases to serve as grammatical subjects, and creating the formal tone expected in scholarly writing.

q_gram_c2_14_005.question: Los resultados ___ sugerir que existe una correlación significativa entre ambas variables. (parecer, present indicative, hedging)
q_gram_c2_14_005.explanation: 'Parecer + infinitive' is a key hedging device in academic Spanish, softening claims to avoid categorical assertions. 'Los resultados parecen sugerir' (the results seem to suggest) is doubly hedged — both 'parecen' and 'sugerir' attenuate the claim. The plural 'parecen' agrees with 'los resultados'.
q_gram_c2_14_005.conjugation_info: parecer (present): parezco, pareces, parece, parecemos, parecéis, parecen

q_gram_c2_14_006.question: A partir de los hallazgos, se ___ la necesidad de ampliar el estudio a una población más diversa.
q_gram_c2_14_006.explanation: 'Se constata la necesidad' uses the impersonal passive 'se' with a singular verb because 'la necesidad' is singular. 'Constatar' (to verify/establish) is a formal academic verb. The present tense conveys the conclusion as a current finding derived from the research.
q_gram_c2_14_006.hint: The verb must agree with the singular subject 'la necesidad'

q_gram_c2_14_007.question: Further research is needed to determine the long-term effects of this intervention.
q_gram_c2_14_007.correct: Se requiere investigación adicional para determinar los efectos a largo plazo de esta intervención.
wrong: Más investigación es necesitada para determinar los efectos a largo plazo de esta intervención.
Necesitamos más investigación para determinar los efectos de largo plazo de esta intervención.
Es necesario que se investigue más para que se determinen los efectos a largo tiempo de esta intervención.
q_gram_c2_14_007.explanation: Academic Spanish avoids the English passive 'is needed' and uses 'se requiere' (impersonal se). 'Investigación adicional' is preferred over 'más investigación' in formal registers. 'A largo plazo' is the correct fixed expression for 'long-term', not 'de largo plazo' or 'a largo tiempo'.

q_gram_c2_14_008.question: Tal y como se ___ en la sección anterior, las limitaciones metodológicas deben tenerse en cuenta al interpretar estos datos.
q_gram_c2_14_008.explanation: 'Tal y como se mencionó en la sección anterior' (as was mentioned in the previous section) uses the impersonal 'se' with the preterite to refer to a specific earlier point in the text. The preterite is preferred here because the mention occurred at a definite point, unlike the imperfect which would imply an ongoing or repeated action.
q_gram_c2_14_008.hint: Use the preterite for a specific past reference within the text

q_gram_c2_14_009.question: No se han hallado diferencias estadísticamente significativas entre los grupos experimentales y el grupo de control.
q_gram_c2_14_009.correct: No statistically significant differences have been found between the experimental groups and the control group.
wrong: Statistically significant differences have not been found between the groups of experiment and the group of control.
There were no differences of statistical significance between the experimental groups and the controlling group.
Significant statistical differences were not encountered between the experimental and the control groups.
q_gram_c2_14_009.explanation: 'Se han hallado' (present perfect with impersonal 'se') translates to the passive 'have been found'. 'Estadísticamente significativas' is a fixed academic collocation meaning 'statistically significant'. 'Grupo de control' = 'control group' (not 'controlling group').

q_gram_c2_14_010.question: Sería conveniente que futuras investigaciones ___ estas variables con una muestra más amplia. (abordar, imperfect subjunctive, formal recommendation)
q_gram_c2_14_010.explanation: 'Sería conveniente que' (it would be advisable that) triggers the imperfect subjunctive because the main clause is in the conditional. 'Abordaran' is the -ra form of the imperfect subjunctive. In academic writing, this structure is used for recommendations. Note: 'abordasen' is also grammatically valid but the -ra form is standard in academic prose.
q_gram_c2_14_010.conjugation_info: abordar (imperfect subjunctive): abordara, abordaras, abordara, abordáramos, abordarais, abordaran

q_gram_c2_15_001.question: Si yo ___ tú, no aceptaría esa oferta. (ser, imperfect subjunctive — a basic conditional structure reviewed at mastery level)
q_gram_c2_15_001.explanation: 'Si yo fuera tú' (if I were you) uses the imperfect subjunctive in the si-clause of a present contrary-to-fact conditional. This is one of the most fundamental structures in Spanish, first encountered at B1-B2 but requiring complete mastery at C2. The conditional 'aceptaría' follows in the main clause.
q_gram_c2_15_001.hint: Contrary-to-fact conditionals require the imperfect subjunctive in the si-clause

q_gram_c2_15_002.question: Habiéndose ___ todas las pruebas, el juez dictó sentencia. (presentar, past participle in absolute participial clause)
q_gram_c2_15_002.explanation: The absolute participial clause 'habiéndose presentado todas las pruebas' (all evidence having been presented) uses the compound gerund: habiendo + past participle. With reflexive 'se', it becomes 'habiéndose presentado'. This is an advanced literary construction that compresses a temporal subordinate clause.

q_gram_c2_15_003.question: What is the difference between 'ser aburrido' and 'estar aburrido'?
q_gram_c2_15_003.correct: 'Ser aburrido' means 'to be boring' (inherent quality), while 'estar aburrido' means 'to be bored' (temporary state)
wrong: Both mean 'to be bored' but 'ser' is more formal than 'estar'
'Ser aburrido' means 'to be bored' and 'estar aburrido' means 'to be boring'
'Ser aburrido' is used for people and 'estar aburrido' is used for things
q_gram_c2_15_003.explanation: The ser/estar distinction with adjectives is fundamental. With 'aburrido': ser describes an inherent characteristic (Juan es aburrido = Juan is a boring person), while estar describes a state or condition (Juan está aburrido = Juan is bored right now). This A2-level concept must be fully mastered by C2.

q_gram_c2_15_004.question: A no ser que se ___ medidas urgentes, la crisis se agravará irreversiblemente. (tomar, present subjunctive)
q_gram_c2_15_004.explanation: 'A no ser que' (unless) always triggers the subjunctive. Since the main clause uses the future ('se agravará'), the subordinate clause takes the present subjunctive 'tomen'. The impersonal 'se' with plural 'medidas' requires the plural form. This tests mastery across subjunctive triggers, tense sequencing, and impersonal constructions.
q_gram_c2_15_004.conjugation_info: tomar (present subjunctive): tome, tomes, tome, tomemos, toméis, tomen

q_gram_c2_15_005.question: El informe, ___ conclusiones fueron cuestionadas por varios expertos, ha sido revisado por completo.
q_gram_c2_15_005.explanation: 'Cuyas' is the feminine plural relative possessive pronoun, agreeing with 'conclusiones' (feminine plural), not with 'el informe' (masculine). 'Cuyo/a/os/as' agrees with the thing possessed, not the possessor. 'Que sus' is ungrammatical in standard Spanish relative clauses.
q_gram_c2_15_005.hint: The relative possessive must agree in gender and number with the possessed noun

q_gram_c2_15_006.question: De haberlo ___ antes, habríamos tomado otra decisión. (saber, past participle — mixed conditional with compound infinitive)
q_gram_c2_15_006.explanation: 'De haberlo sabido' (had we known it) is a compressed conditional structure equivalent to 'Si lo hubiéramos sabido'. The compound infinitive 'haber + past participle' replaces the full si-clause. This is a C1-C2 construction that combines knowledge of conditionals, infinitive clauses, and clitic placement.
q_gram_c2_15_006.conjugation_info: saber (past participle): sabido; compound infinitive: haber sabido

q_gram_c2_15_007.question: Sea ___ sea el resultado, aceptaremos la decisión del tribunal.
q_gram_c2_15_007.explanation: 'Sea cual sea' (whatever/whichever... may be) is a fixed concessive construction using the duplicated present subjunctive of 'ser'. The interrogative pronoun 'cual' is the only correct option in this structure. This formula is used across all registers to express indifference to outcome.

q_gram_c2_15_008.question: Had it not been for your help, we would not have succeeded.
q_gram_c2_15_008.correct: De no haber sido por tu ayuda, no habríamos tenido éxito.
wrong: Si no hubiera sido por tu ayuda, no tuviéramos éxito.
Si no fuera por tu ayuda, no habríamos tenido éxito.
De no ser por tu ayuda, no habríamos tenido éxito.
q_gram_c2_15_008.explanation: 'Had it not been for' requires the past counterfactual: 'De no haber sido por' (compound infinitive construction). 'De no ser por' would mean 'were it not for' (present counterfactual). The main clause uses the conditional perfect 'habríamos tenido éxito' (would have succeeded).

q_gram_c2_15_009.question: Por mucho que se lo ___ , nunca nos hizo caso. (repetir, imperfect subjunctive, nosotros form — concessive clause with quantifier)
q_gram_c2_15_009.explanation: 'Por mucho que' (no matter how much) triggers the subjunctive. The imperfect subjunctive 'repitiéramos' is required because the main clause is in the preterite ('hizo'). Note the stem change: repetir → repit- in the subjunctive (from the third person preterite stem 'repitió'). The clitic 'se lo' precedes the conjugated verb.
q_gram_c2_15_009.conjugation_info: repetir (imperfect subjunctive): repitiera, repitieras, repitiera, repitiéramos, repitierais, repitieran

q_gram_c2_15_010.question: Dicho sea de paso, no es la primera vez que se incumple el protocolo establecido, lo cual pone en entredicho la credibilidad de la institución.
q_gram_c2_15_010.correct: Incidentally, it is not the first time that the established protocol has been breached, which calls into question the institution's credibility.
wrong: Said in passing, it is not the first time they don't comply with the established protocol, which puts in between-said the credibility of the institution.
By the way, it is not the first time that the established protocol is unfulfilled, the which puts into question the credibility of the institution.
That said in passing, this is not the first time the protocol was not complied with, which casts doubt on the institution's credibility.
q_gram_c2_15_010.explanation: 'Dicho sea de paso' is a fixed parenthetical expression meaning 'incidentally / by the way'. 'Se incumple' (impersonal se + present) translates as 'has been breached' to capture the resultative meaning. 'Poner en entredicho' is an idiom meaning 'to call into question / to undermine'. This sentence tests mastery of multiple advanced structures simultaneously.
